case_name: Motor Industries Company Employees Association v. Motor Industries Company

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the Award dated March 23, 1968 of the Labour Court, Bangalore in Reference No. 39 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Award dated March 23, 1968 of the Labour Court, Bangalore in Reference No. 39 of 1967.

facts.text: Industrial dispute between the respondent-company and the Motor Industries Company Employees Association referred to the Labour Court, Bangalore, under S. 10(1) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, founded on special leave, arises out ,of an industrial dispute between the respondent-company and the Motor Industries Company Employees Association which the Government of Mysore referred to the Labour Court, Bangalore, for adjudication under S. 10  1   c  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

facts.text: Management dismissed three workmen: Sandhyavoo, G. Prabhakar and M. V. Vasudevan out of five after domestic enquiry finding them guilty of misconduct.

anchor.surface_text: The dispute related to the dismissal by the management of three workmen, Sandhyavoo, G. Prabhakar and M. V. Vasudevan out of the five workmen against whom the management had held a domestic enquiry at which they were found guilty of acts of misconduct charged against them.

facts.text: On August 24, 1964 the association handed over to the management a charter of demands.

anchor.surface_text: The facts leading to the said dispute and the reference are as follows On August 24, 1964 the said association handed over to the management a charter of demands.

facts.text: Settlement dated December 23, 1964 arrived at between parties before conciliation officer after failed negotiations.

anchor.surface_text: Negotiations between the parties having failed, the demands were taken before the companyciliation officer when the parties arrived at a settlement dated December 23, 1964.

facts.text: On April 29, 1966, management issued notice suspending B. G. Shenoy for a day on May 4, 1966 as penalty.

anchor.surface_text: On April 29, 1966, the management issued a numberice suspending for a day, i.e., May 4, 1966, one B. G. Shenoy as and by way of penalty.

facts.text: On May 10, 1966, management served charge-sheet on Shenoy and suspended him pending enquiry after postponing suspension due to protest.

anchor.surface_text: In companysequence of a protest by the association, the said suspension was postponed and on May 10, 1966, the management served -a charge-sheet on Shenoy and suspended him pending an enquiry.

facts.text: On May 11, 1966, association demanded withdrawal of suspension and charge-sheet on Shenoy; discussions from 9.45 A.M. to 12.30 P.M., adjourned for lunch to resume at 2.30 P.M.

anchor.surface_text: On May 11, 1966 the association demanded withdrawal of the said suspension and the said charge-sheet. Discussions took place on that day from 9.45 A.M. to 12.30 P.M. between the association and the management and the parties thereafter adjourned at 1 P.M. for lunch having decided to resume the talks at 2.30 P.M.

facts.text: On May 11, 1966 at 2 P.M., first shift ended, second shift workers joined staying first shift workers and all went on strike.

anchor.surface_text: At 2 P.M. the first shift ended and the workers of the second shift began to companye, in. The workmen of the first shift, however, stayed on and those of the second shift along with the workmen of the general shift joined them and all of them went on strike.

facts.text: Discussions resumed at 2.30 P.M. on May 11, 1966 ended in agreement at 5 P.M., workmen returned to work.

anchor.surface_text: The discussions which were resumed at 2.30 P.M. ended in an agreement at 5 M. and the workmen returned to work.

facts.text: On May 18, 1966, assistant establishment officer submitted complaint to chief personnel officer alleging misconduct by crowd including five workmen: Sandhyavoo, Prabhakar, Vasudevan.

anchor.surface_text: On May 18, 1966 the assistant establishment officer submitted a companyplaint to the chief personnel officer alleging certain acts of misconduct by a crowd of workmen mentioning therein the names of five of them including the said three workmen.

facts.text: On May 25, 1966, charge-sheets served on five workmen for stoppage of work, abandoning place, inciting clerks/officers of G.2 dept, disorderly behaviour including intimidation and assault on A. Lakshman Rao.

anchor.surface_text: On May 25, 1966 charge-sheets alleging stoppage of work, abandoning the place of work, inciting clerks and officers of G. 2 department to join the said strike, disorderly behaviour including intimidation and assault on one, A. Lakshman Rao, were served upon those five workmen.

facts.text: Domestic enquiry held on June 30, 1966, completed July 27, 1966; enquiry officer found three workmen guilty under standing orders 22(2,3,13,18), exonerated other two except on participation under 2 and 18.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, a domestic enquiry was held on June 30, 1966 which was companypleted on July 27, 1966 when the enquiry officer made his report holding the said three workmen, Sandhyavoo, Prabhakar and Vasudevan, guilty of acts of misconduct under standing order 22  2  ,  3  ,  13  and  18 .

facts.text: On August 12, 1966, management agreed with enquiry report and passed dismissal orders against three workmen.

anchor.surface_text: On August 12, 1966, the management, agreeing with the report, passed orders of dismissal against the said three workmen which gave rise to the said reference.

facts.text: Labour Court award on March 23, 1968 held enquiry valid and management justified in dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: On March 23, 1968 the Labour Court gave its award holding that the said enquiry was validly held and that the management were justified in passing the said orders of dismissal.

facts.text: Petitioner contended strike was spontaneous, not called by association, not illegal under S.24 or SO 22(2,3).

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Ramamurthi, appearing for the association, challenged the said award on the following grounds  1  that the said association number having given a call for the said strike, the said charges were misconceived and the orders of dismissal were companysequently number sustainable  2  that the said strike, which was spontaneously staged by the workmen, was number illegal under s. 24 of the Industrial Disputes Act,

facts.text: Petitioner claimed disciplinary proceedings contravened May 11, 1966 agreement, amounting to unfair labour practice.

anchor.surface_text: 3  that the said disciplinary proceedings were in companytravention of the agreement arrived -at on May 11, 1966, and therefore, the dismissal following such disciplinary proceedings amounted to unfair labour practice

facts.text: Court found settlement dated Dec 23, 1964 binding on workmen under ID Act S.18(3), prohibited strike without 4 days notice under Cl.5.

anchor.surface_text: The companystruction of cl. 5 of the settlement suggested by Mr. Ramamurthi is companytrary to  a  the tenor of that settlement,  b  the provisions of the Industrial Disputes Act under which a settlement arrived at between an employer and a union representing the employees during companyciliation proceedings is binding number only on such union but also the workmen whom it represents

facts.text: Strike on May 11, 1966 was lightning strike without notice, not at call of association, in breach of Cl.5 of settlement, illegal under S.29 ID Act.

anchor.surface_text: The strike was a lightning one, was resorted to without numberice and was number at the call of the association and was, therefore, in breach of cl. 5. ... However, the strike was in companytravention of cl. 5 of the said settlement and that settlement being binding on the workmen companycerned and in operation at the time was punish- able under s. 29, and therefore, illegal under that section.

facts.text: Labour Court found no proof that May 11, 1966 agreement included no disciplinary action against workmen for strike.

anchor.surface_text: The Labour Court on this evidence held that the association failed to prove that the management had agreed number to take action against any of the workmen in companynection with the strike though it may be that they might have agreed number to victimise any workman for participating in the strike.

facts.text: Enquiry officer accepted evidence of intimidation and disorderly behaviour by three workmen against A. Lakshman Rao and others.

anchor.surface_text: The report of the enquiry officer against the said Vasudevan clearly stated that the enquiry officer accepted the evidence of the managements witnesses and that on that evidence -all the charges against him stood proved.

facts.text: Court upheld that three workmen were leaders in forefront of crowd forcing into G.2 dept, intimidating officers.

anchor.surface_text: The evidence in the enquiry clearly disclosed that when the crowd forced its way into the G. 2 department it was led by these three workmen, all of whom were in the forefront thereof and two of them had defiantly forced the officers to leave their tables.

facts.text: Dismissal not victimization as three workmen guilty of graver misconduct (incitement, disorderly) than others.

anchor.surface_text: Once a misconduct graver than that of the rest was found proved against these three workmen and for which the punishment is dismissal, victimisation cannot legitimately be attributed to the management

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upholding Labour Court award.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment the orders of dismissal, based on the findings in the domestic enquiry which did number suffer from -any infirmity, companyld number be successfully impeached, and therefore, the Labour Court was right in upholding them. The appeal fails and is dismissed.
Appeal by special leave
S. 10  1   c  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The argument on which the first contention was based was that the settlement dated December 23, 1964 was arrived at between three parties, the management, the association and the men, and that the association being the union registered under the Trade Unions Act was an entity distinct from the workmen. Under cl. 5 of the settlement it was the association which was obliged to give four days numberice if it decided to resort to strike, go-slow tactics or other companyrcive action.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: registered under the Trade Unions Act was an entity distinct from the workmen. Under cl. 5 of the settlement it was the association which was obliged

arguments.claim: Settlement cl.5 second part: association to cooperate in disciplinary action if workmen strike without association call

anchor.surface_text: The second part provided an undertaking on the part of the association to cooperate with the management, if there was any strike by workmen without any call therefore from the association, if the management were to take disciplinary action against the workmen.

arguments.claim: Management did not agree to no action for strike, only perhaps no victimisation

anchor.surface_text: In fact, the management did not impose any penalty against any workman for joining the strike, not even against the three concerned workmen.

holdings.text: The construction of cl. 5 of the settlement suggested by Mr. Ramamurthi is contrary to (a) the tenor of that settlement, (b) the provisions of the Industrial Disputes Act under which a settlement arrived at between an employer and a union representing the employees during conciliation proceedings is binding not only on such union but also the workmen whom it represents and (c) the principles of collective bargaining recognised by industrial law.

anchor.surface_text: In our view this argument cannot be sustained. The construction of cl. 5 of the settlement suggested by Mr. Ramamurthi is contrary to  a  the tenor of that settlement,  b  the provisions of the Industrial Disputes Act under which a settlement arrived at between an employer and a union representing the employees during conciliation proceedings is binding not only on such union but also the workmen whom it represents and  c  the principles of collective bargaining recognised by industrial law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual and purposive interpretation of cl.5 prohibits direct action without notice by workmen even without union call; reinforced by S.18(3) binding nature and collective bargaining principles.

holdings.text: The strike was in contravention of cl. 5 of the said settlement and that settlement being binding on the workmen concerned and in operation at the time was punishable under s. 29, and therefore, illegal under that section.

anchor.surface_text: However, the strike was in contravention of cl. 5 of the said settlement and that settlement being binding on the workmen concerned and in operation at the time was punishable under s. 29, and therefore, illegal under that section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Breach of binding settlement (S.18(3)) punishable under S.29 renders strike illegal, distinct from S.23/24; applies to SO22 misconduct.

holdings.text: Consequently, standing order 22 would apply and participating in or inciting others to join such a strike would amount to misconduct for which the management were entitled to take disciplinary action.

anchor.surface_text: The strike was illegal not under s. 24 but because it was in contravention of the settlement binding on the workmen concerned. Consequently, standing order 22 would apply and participating in or inciting -others to join such a strike would amount to misconduct for which ,the management were entitled to take disciplinary action.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Illegal strike under S.29 constitutes contravention of law under SO22(2),(3),(13),(18).

holdings.text: The association failed to prove that the management had agreed not to take action against any of the workmen in connection with the strike though it may be that they might have agreed not to victimise any workman for participating in the strike.

anchor.surface_text: The Labour Court on this evidence held that the association failed to prove that the management had agreed not to take action against any of the workmen in connection with the strike though it may be that they might have agreed not to victimise any workman for participating in the strike.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Oral agreement unproved; Labour Court fact-finding concurrent and reasoned, no perversity warranting interference.

holdings.text: Acceptance of this evidence by the enquiry officer must necessarily mean acceptance of the version of these officers that they were intimidated by the crowd which forced its way into their department led by these three workmen. Though the enquiry officer has not, in so many words, used the expression intimidation his finding of disorderly behaviour must be held to include acts of intimidation.

anchor.surface_text: Acceptance of this evidence by the enquiry officer must necessarily mean acceptance of the version of these officers that they were intimidated by the crowd which forced its way into their department led by these three workmen. Though the enquiry officer has not, in so many words, used the expression intimidation his finding of disorderly behaviour must be held to include acts of intimidation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Enquiry officer accepted management's witness evidence of threats and forcing out, subsumed under disorderly behaviour (SO22(13)).

holdings.text: Once a misconduct graver than that of the rest was found proved against these three workmen and for which the punishment is dismissal, victimisation cannot legitimately be attributed to the management.

anchor.surface_text: Once a misconduct graver than that of the rest was found proved against these three workmen and for which the punishment is dismissal, victimisation cannot legitimately be attributed to the management

holdings.reasoning_summary: Leaders in forefront committed incitement/disorderly acts graver than mere participation; no unequal treatment among unequals.

holdings.text: In our judgment the orders of dismissal, based on the findings in the domestic enquiry which did not suffer from any infirmity, could not be successfully impeached, and therefore, the Labour Court was right in upholding them.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment the orders of dismissal, based on the findings in the domestic enquiry which did not suffer from -any infirmity, could not be successfully impeached, and therefore, the Labour Court was right in upholding them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Enquiry findings evidence-based, not perverse; Labour Court upheld validly; no Wednesbury unreasonableness.

holdings.text: The decision in the present case must be the same [as Tata Engineering case]. The strike was illegal not under s. 24 but because it was in contravention of the settlement binding on the workmen concerned.

anchor.surface_text: In our view the decision in the present case must be the same. The strike was illegal not under s. 24 but because it was in contravention of the settlement binding on the workmen concerned.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogous to Tata case: lightning strike breaching no-notice clause in settlement illegal under S.29.

precedents.citation: The Tata Engineering and Locomotive Co. Ltd. v. C. B. Mitter Anr.

anchor.surface_text: The Tata Engineering and Locomotive Co. Ltd. v. C. B. Mitter Anr. As in cl. 5 of the settlement before us, the settlement there also provided that in no case would the parties thereto resort to direct action such as lockouts, strikes, go-slow and other direct action without four days notice.

precedents.case_name: Tata Engineering and Locomotive Co. Ltd. v. C. B. Mitter
precedents.cited_proposition: a strike commenced without notice in contravention of a settlement clause prohibiting direct action without four days' notice is illegal under s. 29 of the Industrial Disputes Act even if not illegal under s. 24
precedents.cited_holding: the words 'in no case' meant a strike for whatever reason and it was illegal because it was in contravention of the settlement binding on the concerned workmen

anchor.surface_text: In our view this argument cannot be sustained. The construction of cl. 5 of the settlement suggested by Mr. Ramamurthi is contrary to  a  the tenor of that settlement,  b  the provisions of the Industrial Disputes Act under which a settlement arrived at between an employer and a union representing the employees during conciliation proceedings is binding not only on such union but also the workmen whom it represents and  c  the principles of collective bargaining recognised by industrial law.
The appeal fails and is dismissed.
